abstract.p: This document defines the JSON schema for testing FIPS Pub 186 EdDSA implementations with the ACVP specification.

organization.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology

localized-strings.localized-string:
This document is currently under development and is
NOT INTENDED FOR PUBLIC RELEASE.

This document is currently under development. The draft is not yet complete, and organizations should not attempt to implement it. The content is in an early stage of development, rough, incomplete and experimental; it has not been extensively edited or vetted. This provides an insider view of the iterative process to develop the content and it gives NIST an opportunity to share early thoughts, ideas, and approaches with the community. NIST welcomes early informal feedback and comments, which will be adjudicated after the specified public comment period.

This document incorporates comments from the work-in-progress draft. It is a relatively cohesive document and is considered stable, although there are gaps in the content and the overall document is incomplete. Some changes are expected. Organizations may consider experimenting with guidelines, with the understanding that they will identify gaps and challenges. NIST welcomes early informal feedback and comments, which will be adjudicated after the specified public comment period; a full public draft is expected to follow.

This draft represents a complete document that is released for public comment as part of NIST’s official review process, in support of an open and transparent process for developing guidelines and standards. The language is normalized and is consistent throughout the document. Comments received during previous review cycles (if any) have been adjudicated and are addressed in this release. Early adopters may attempt to implement the guidelines in a test or development environment; however, comments received on this draft may cause NIST to determine that a subsequent public draft and comment period are necessary. The content of this document will not be considered “final” until it is formally published and announced by NIST.
This document has been superseded by the document identified below. It will remain active until the withdrawal date, when it will be officially withdrawn.
The attached draft document has been RETIRED. NIST has discontinued additional development of this document, which is provided here in its entirety for historical purposes.
The attached draft document has been withdrawn, and is provided solely for historical purposes. It has been superseded by the document identified below.
The attached publication has been withdrawn (archived), and is provided solely for historical purposes. It may have been superseded by another publication (indicated below).

clause.title: Disclaimer
clause.p: Any mention of commercial products or reference to commercial organizations is for information only; it does not imply recommendation or endorsement by NIST, nor does it imply that the products mentioned are necessarily the best available for the purpose.

clause.title: Additional Information
clause.p: For additional information on NIST’s Cybersecurity programs, projects and publications, visit the Computer Security Resource Center. Information on other efforts at NIST and in the Information Technology Laboratory (ITL) is also available.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: This document defines the JSON schema for testing FIPS Pub 186 EdDSA implementations with the ACVP specification.

clause.title: Keywords
clause.p: The following are keywords to be used by search engines and document catalogues.
ACVP; cryptography

foreword.title: Foreword
foreword.p: The Information Technology Laboratory (ITL) at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) promotes the U.S. economy and public welfare by providing technical leadership for the Nation’s measurement and standards infrastructure. ITL develops tests, test methods, reference data, proof of concept implementations, and technical analyses to advance the development and productive use of information technology. ITL’s responsibilities include the development of management, administrative, technical, and physical standards and guidelines for the cost-effective security and privacy of other than national security-related information in federal information systems. The Special Publication 800-series reports on ITL’s research, guidelines, and outreach efforts in information system security, and its collaborative activities with industry, government, and academic organizations.

clause.title: Audience
clause.p: This document is intended for the users and developers of ACVP.

clause.title: Conventions
clause.p: The key words “MUST”, “MUST NOT”, “REQUIRED”, “SHALL”, “SHALL NOT”, “SHOULD”, “SHOULD NOT”, “RECOMMENDED”, “NOT RECOMMENDED”, “MAY”, and “OPTIONAL” in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 of [RFC 2119] and [RFC 8174] when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

acknowledgements.title: Acknowledgements
acknowledgements.p: This document is produced by the Security Testing, Validation and Measurement group under the Automated Cryptographic Validation Testing (ACVT) program.

executivesummary.title: Executive Summary
executivesummary.p: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing FIPS Pub 186 EdDSA implementations using ACVP.

clause.title: 1.Introduction
clause.p: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing FIPS Pub 186 EdDSA implementations using ACVP.

clause.title: 2.Supported EDDSA Algorithms
clause.p: The following EDDSA algorithms MAY be advertised by the ACVP compliant cryptographic module:

clause.title: 3.1.Test Types
clause.p: The ACVP server performs a set of tests on the specified EDDSA algorithm in order to assess the correctness and robustness of the implementation. A typical ACVP validation session SHALL require multiple tests to be performed for every supported permutation of EDDSA capabilities. This section describes the design of the tests used to validate implementations of the EDDSA algorithms.

li.p: EDDSA / keyGen / 1.0 “AFT” — Algorithm Functional Test. The IUT is REQUIRED for each test case provided, to generate a key pair based on an approved curve. This information is then communicated to the ACVP server and validated.

EDDSA / keyVer / 1.0 “AFT” — Algorithm Functional Test. The ACVP server is REQUIRED to generate a series of keys based on the IUT provided NIST curve(s). The keys generated by the server MAY or MAY NOT be valid, the IUT is REQUIRED to determine if the keys provided in the test cases are valid or invalid keys as they relate to the curve.

EDDSA / sigGen / 1.0 “AFT” — Algorithm Functional Test. This testing mode expects the IUT to generate valid signatures based on the ACVP provided message. The signature is then validated with the ACVP server given the IUT’s communicated curve, public key, and signature.

EDDSA / sigGen / 1.0 “BFT” — Bit Flip Test. This testing mode produces a single message and flips individual bits in the message to ensure a client is able to produce distinct signatures for each message.

EDDSA / sigVer / 1.0 “AFT” — Algorithm Functional Test. The ACVP server generates a series of signatures to communicate to the IUT. The IUT is REQUIRED to determine the validity of the signature given the curve, key, and message.

clause.title: 4.Capabilities Registration
clause.p: ACVP requires crypto modules to register their capabilities. This allows the crypto module to advertise support for specific algorithms, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process. This section describes the constructs for advertising support of EdDSA algorithms to the ACVP server.

The algorithm capabilities MUST be advertised as JSON objects within the ‘algorithms’ value of the ACVP registration message. The ‘algorithms’ value is an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The ‘algorithms’ value is part of the ‘capability_exchange’ element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification [ACVP] for more details on the registration message.

clause.title: 4.1.Prerequisites
clause.p: Each algorithm implementation MAY rely on other cryptographic primitives. For example, RSA Signature algorithms depend on an underlying hash function. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

Prerequisites, if applicable, MUST be submitted in the registration as the prereqVals JSON property array inside each element of the algorithms array. Each element in the prereqVals array MUST contain the following properties

table.name: Table 1 — Prerequisite Properties

clause.p: A “valValue” of “same” SHALL be used to indicate that the prerequisite is being met by a different algorithm in the capability exchange in the same registration.
An example description of prerequisites within a single algorithm capability exchange looks like this

clause.title: 4.2.Required Prerequisite Algorithms for EDDSA Validations
clause.p: Each EDDSA implementation relies on other cryptographic primitives. For example, EDDSA uses an underlying SHA algorithm. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

table.name: Table 2 — Required EDDSA Prerequisite Algorithms JSON Values

tr.td: object with algorithm and valValue properties

clause.title: 4.3.EDDSA Algorithm Capabilities Registration
clause.p: Each algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object using the following values

table.name: Table 3 — EDDSA Algorithm Capabilities JSON Values

tr.td: The EDDSA mode to be validated
The algorithm testing revision to use

clause.p: The follwing sections offer additional REQUIRED JSON properties for each algorithm / mode / revision.

clause.title: 4.3.1.The EDDSA keyGen Mode Capabilities
clause.p: Each EDDSA keyGen mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

clause.title: 4.3.1.1.EDDSA keyGen Full Set of Capabilities
clause.p: The complete list of EDDSA key generation capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

table.name: Table 4 — EDDSA keyGen Capabilities JSON Values

tr.td: The curve names supported for the IUT in keyGen
The method used to generate the randomness incoporated in the key
Any non-empty subset of {”extra bits”, “testing candidates”}

note.name: NOTE
note.p: More information on the ‘secretGenerationMode’ can be found in Appendix A.2 in [FIPS 186-5 (Draft)].

clause.p: An example of this is the following

clause.title: 4.3.2.The EDDSA keyVer Mode Capabilities
clause.p: Each EDDSA keyVer mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

clause.title: 4.3.2.1.keyVer Full Set of Capabilities
clause.p: The complete list of EDDSA key verification capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

table.name: Table 5 — EDDSA keyVer Capabilities JSON Values

tr.td: The curve names supported for the IUT in keyVer

clause.p: An example of this is the following

clause.title: 4.3.3.The sigGen Mode Capabilities
clause.p: Each EDDSA sigGen mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

clause.title: 4.3.3.1.sigGen Full Set of Capabilities
clause.p: The complete list of EDDSA signature generation capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

table.name: Table 6 — EDDSA sigGen Capabilities JSON Values

tr.td: The curve names supported for the IUT in sigGen
If the IUT supports normal ‘pure’ EdDSA signature generation functionality
If the IUT supports Prehash EdDSA, i.e., HashEdDSA, signature generation functionality

clause.p: The following is an example

clause.title: 4.3.4.The sigVer Mode Capabilities
clause.p: Each EDDSA sigVer mode capability set is advertised as a self-contained JSON object.

clause.title: 4.3.4.1.sigVer Full Set of Capabilities
clause.p: The complete list of EDDSA signature verification capabilities may be advertised by the ACVP compliant crypto module:

table.name: Table 7 — EDDSA sigVer Capabilities JSON Values

tr.td: The curve names supported for the IUT in sigGen
If the IUT supports normal ‘pure’ sigGen functionality
If the IUT supports accepting a preHashed message to sign

clause.p: The following is an example

clause.title: 5.Test Vectors
clause.p: The ACVP server provides test vectors to the ACVP client, which are then processed and returned to the ACVP server for validation. A typical ACVP validation session would require multiple test vector sets to be downloaded and processed by the ACVP client. Each test vector set represents an individual EdDSA function. This section describes the JSON schema for a test vector set used with EdDSA algorithms.

The test vector set JSON schema is a multi-level hierarchy that contains meta data for the entire vector set as well as individual test vectors to be processed by the ACVP client.The following table describes the JSON elements at the top level of the hierarchy.

table.name: Table 8 — Vector Set JSON Object

tr.td: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Algorithm defined in the capability exchange
Mode defined in the capability exchange
Array of test group JSON objects, which are defined in Section 5.1, Section 5.3, Section 5.5, and Section 5.7

clause.p: An example of this would look like this

clause.title: 5.1.EDDSA keyGen Test Groups JSON Schema
clause.p: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.
The test group for EDDSA / keyGen / 1.0 is as follows:

table.name: Table 9 — EDDSA keyGen Test Group JSON Object

tr.td: The curve type used for the test vectors
The method of generating a secret used for key generation in the test vectors
Array of individual test vector JSON objects, which are defined in Section 5.2

clause.title: 5.2.EDDSA keyGen Test Case JSON Schema
clause.p: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each EDDSA test vector.

table.name: Table 10 — Test Case JSON Object

tr.td: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set

note.name: NOTE
note.p: The client is responsible for generating a single key per test case.

clause.p: The following is an example of a prompt for EDDSA / keyGen / 1.0

clause.title: 5.3.EDDSA keyVer Test Groups JSON Schema
clause.p: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.
The test group for EDDSA / keyVer / 1.0 is as follows:

table.name: Table 11 — EDDSA keyVer Test Group JSON Object

tr.td: The curve type used for the test vectors
Array of individual test vector JSON objects, which are defined in Section 5.4

clause.title: 5.4.EDDSA keyVer Test Case JSON Schema
clause.p: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each EDDSA test vector.

table.name: Table 12 — Test Case JSON Object

tr.td: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set
The encoded public key curve point

clause.p: The following is an example of a prompt for EDDSA / keyVer / 1.0

clause.title: 5.5.EDDSA sigGen Test Groups JSON Schema
clause.p: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.
The test group for EDDSA / sigGen / 1.0 is as follows:

table.name: Table 13 — EDDSA sigGen Test Group JSON Object

tr.td: The curve type used for the test vectors
Whether or not Prehash EdDSA/HashEdDSA (vs normal/’pure’ EdDSA) should be used for the test vectors
Array of individual test vector JSON objects, which are defined in Section 5.6

clause.title: 5.6.EDDSA sigGen Test Case JSON Schema
clause.p: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each EDDSA test vector.

table.name: Table 14 — Test Case JSON Object

tr.td: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set
The message used to generate the signature
The context string defined in FIPS 186-5 sections 7.6 and 7.8

note.name: NOTE
note.p: The ‘context’ property will only be present for 1) normal/’pure’ EdDSA signature generation tests that use Ed448 and 2) Prehash EdDSA/HashEdDSA signature generation tests that use Ed448 or Ed25519.

clause.p: The following is an example of a prompt for EDDSA / sigGen / 1.0

clause.title: 5.7.EDDSA sigVer Test Groups JSON Schema
clause.p: The testGroups element at the top level in the test vector JSON object is an array of test groups. Test vectors are grouped into similar test cases to reduce the amount of data transmitted in the vector set. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The Test Group JSON object contains meta data that applies to all test vectors within the group. The following table describes the JSON elements of the Test Group JSON object.
The test group for EDDSA / sigVer / 1.0 is as follows:

table.name: Table 15 — EDDSA sigVer Test Group JSON Object

tr.td: The curve type used for the test vectors
Whether or not Prehash EdDSA/HashEdDSA (vs normal/’pure’ EdDSA) should be used for the test vectors
Array of individual test vector JSON objects, which are defined in Section 5.8

clause.title: 5.8.EDDSA sigVer Test Case JSON Schema
clause.p: Each test group contains an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test vector to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each EDDSA test vector.

table.name: Table 16 — Test Case JSON Object

tr.td: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set
The message used to generate the signature

clause.p: The following is an example of a prompt for EDDSA / sigVer / 1.0

clause.title: 6.Test Vector Responses
clause.p: After the ACVP client downloads and processes a vector set, it must send the response vectors back to the ACVP server. The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response.

table.name: Table 17 — Vector Set Response JSON Object

tr.td: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Array of JSON objects that are defined in Section 6.1, Section 6.2, Section 6.3 and Section 6.4

clause.title: 6.1.EDDSA keyGen Test Group Responses
clause.p: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test group response for EDDSA / keyGen / 1.0.

table.name: Table 18 — EDDSA keyGen Test Group Response JSON Object

tr.td: Unique numeric identifier for the test group
Array of JSON objects that represent each result, as defined by the table below

clause.p: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test case response for EDDSA / keyGen / 1.0.

table.name: Table 19 — EDDSA keyGen Test Case Response JSON Object

clause.p: The following is an example of the response for EDDSA / keyGen / 1.0

clause.title: 6.2.EDDSA keyVer Test Group Responses
clause.p: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test group response for EDDSA / keyVer / 1.0.

table.name: Table 20 — EDDSA keyVer Test Group Response JSON Object

tr.td: Unique numeric identifier for the test group
Array of JSON objects that represent each result, as defined by the table below

clause.p: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test case response for EDDSA / keyVer / 1.0.

table.name: Table 21 — EDDSA keyVer Test Case Response JSON Object

tr.td: Whether or not the key provided was valid

clause.p: The following is an example of the response for EDDSA / keyVer / 1.0

clause.title: 6.3.EDDSA sigGen Test Group Responses
clause.p: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test group response for EDDSA / sigGen / 1.0.

table.name: Table 22 — EDDSA sigGen Test Group Response JSON Object

tr.td: Unique numeric identifier for the test group
The encoded public key point used for signatures in the group
Array of JSON objects that represent each result, as defined by the table below

clause.p: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test case response for EDDSA / sigGen / 1.0.

table.name: Table 23 — EDDSA sigGen Test Case Response JSON Object

clause.p: The following is an example of the response for EDDSA / sigGen / 1.0

clause.title: 6.4.EDDSA sigVer Test Group Responses
clause.p: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test group response for EDDSA / sigVer / 1.0.

table.name: Table 24 — EDDSA sigVer Test Group Response JSON Object

tr.td: Unique numeric identifier for the test group
Array of JSON objects that represent each result, as defined by the table below

clause.p: The following table describes the JSON object that represents a test case response for EDDSA / sigVer / 1.0.

table.name: Table 25 — EDDSA sigVer Test Case Response JSON Object

tr.td: Whether or not the signature provided was valid

clause.p: The following is an example of the response for EDDSA / sigVer / 1.0

clause.title: 7.Security Considerations
clause.p: There are no additional security considerations outside of those outlined in the ACVP document.

annex.title: Appendix A — Terminology
annex.p: For the purposes of this document, the following terms and definitions apply.

definition.p: JSON sent from the server to the client describing the tests the client performs
The initial request from the client to the server describing the capabilities of one or several algorithm, mode and revision combinations
JSON sent from the client to the server in response to the prompt
An individual unit of work within a prompt or response
A collection of test cases that share similar properties within a prompt or response
A collection of test groups under a specific algorithm, mode, and revision
JSON sent from the server to the client that specifies the correctness of the response

table.name: Table C-1
